ProcedureHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PROC SERVER <options>;
    ALLOCATE SASFILE SAS-data-set1 <(data-set-options) >  
      <SAS-data-set2> <(data-set-options) ... SAS-data-set8 <(data-set-options)>>  
    ALLOCATE LIBRARY libref <engine> 'SAS-data-library' <LIBTYPE=library-type>
  <CATCACHELIMIT=n><engine/system-options>;  
  
The SERVER procedure is the core of SAS/SHARE. It is the component that enables
two or more clients to write concurrently to the same SAS file. To start a
SAS/SHARE server, invoke the SERVER procedure. Specify an ID for that server
with a set of optional parameters that define the server behavior.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ALLOC]
      
 The ALLOC option enables clients to define libraries to a server.

[Syntax: NOALLOC]   
      
 The NOALLOC option prevents clients from defining additional libraries to the
 server and restricts clients to accessing libraries that are defined by a
 server administrator.

[Syntax: ACCTLVL=value | (value 1 < ... value n >) ]      
      
Specifies the level of accounting. Use this option to specify the aggregation
(or detail) used in reporting server usage statistics. This option is useful
for tuning an application because it enables you to examine, in more detail,
how various parts of the application use the server resources. The usage
statistics also enable you to charge users for the amount of server resources
they consume.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the server to log statistics every time a SAS file is closed by a user.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes the server to log statistics every time a user disconnects from the server.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Causes the server to log statistics every time a user terminates a resource environment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Causes the server to log statistics for all accounting levels (DATA, USER, and  RESOURCE_ENVIRONMENT).

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ADMINLIBREF=value | _NONE_ ]      
      
Specifies the libref associated with the library of administrative data for the
server. This option enables a client to handle a server's administrative data
in the same way it handles any other SAS file, which enables the client to
process that data programmatically. To turn off this type of access to a
server's administrative data, specify ADMINLIBREF=_NONE_.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Turn off access to a server's administrative data.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: AUTHENTICATE=REQUIRED | OPTIONAL ]      
      
Controls whether a server requires connecting users to provide a valid user ID
and password when they connect to the server. You can use this option with a
communications access method security option (for example, use the TCPSEC
option for TCP/IP).

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: The security options of all the access methods that are used by the server must be set to _SECURE_.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: The communications access method security options might be set to _SECURE_.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: CLIENTID = SESSION | SECURITY ]      
      
Specifies the source of the client user ID to use in log messages that are
written to the server log. Your choice determines the search order that is used
to locate the client user ID.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the source of the client user ID is either the logon name or the batch  account name of the client session.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the source of the user ID is the secured name that the client used to  connect to the server.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DTFORMAT=SAS-datetime-format |_NODTS_ ]      
      
Specifies the format for the date-and-time stamp at the beginning of each
message that is written to the server log. You can specify any SAS date, time,
or date-and-time format; or you can specify your own date-and-time format.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifying the value _NODTS_ suppresses the date-and-time stamp.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LRPYIELD=value ]      
      
Indicates, to a long-running process in the server's SAS session, how
frequently the process should yield so that others can use the server. The
default is 10000; this value has no units. Increase the value to have a 
long-running process yield more frequently; decrease the value to have it yield
less frequently. LRPYIELD=0 does not yield at all. With a 0 value, the server
can process other requests only after the long-running process has finished.

[Syntax: LOG=value|(value 1 <... value n>) ]      
      
Causes the server to log specific usage statistics about client/server
transactions and SQL queries that it receives through the Remote SQL
Pass-Through facility. This is useful for application tuning and for charging
clients for the amount of server resources they consume. The server writes one
line to its log for each resource statistic that is specified.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the server to log the cumulative elapsed time of server processing for the  specified event in the ACCTLVL= option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes the server to log the cumulative number of bytes that are transferred between  the client and the server for the event that is being logged.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Causes the server to log the elapsed time of the recorded event.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Causes the server to log the number of client requests that are processed by the  server for the recorded event.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Causes the server to log each SQL query that it receives through the Remote SQL  Pass-Through facility from a SAS session or other client.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Causes the server to log all the usage statistics (ACTIVETIME, BYTECOUNT, ELAPSEDTIME,  and MESSAGE) for the corresponding accounting level.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Causes the server to log the total number of connections and maximum concurrent number  of connections from thin clients that access the SAS/SHARE server.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: MSGNUMBER ]      
      
Associates a unique message number (represented in hexadecimal notation) with
each type of operation for which a message is recorded in a server log.

[Syntax: NORMTVIEW ]      
      
Disables the ability of a server to interpret SAS data views.

[Syntax: OAPW=password | "encoded-password" ]      
      
Specifies a password that you must supply (by using the OPERATE procedure) to
connect to the server.

[Syntax: PT2DBPW=password | "encoded-password" ]      
      
Specifies the client password for controlling pass-through access to a remote DBMS.

[Syntax: SERVERID=server-ID | _ _port-number ]      
      
Specifies the name of a server.

[Syntax: THREADEDTCP | TTCP ]      
      
Specifies whether the threaded version of the TCP access method and associated threaded infrastructure should be used when TCP/IP communication is specified.

[Syntax: NOTHREADEDTCP | NOTTCP ]      
      
Specifies whether the threaded version of the TCP access method and associated threaded infrastructure should be used when TCP/IP communication is specified.

[Syntax: TBUFSIZE=value ]      
      
Specifies the suggested size of a buffer that the server uses to transmit information to a client or receive information from a client.

[Syntax: UAPW=password | "encoded-password" ]      
      
Specifies a password that a client must supply in the LIBNAME statement to establish communication with the server.

[Syntax: WORKTASKS = initial | ( <initial> <, maximum> ) ]      
      
Specifies the initial and maximum number of work tasks for the SAS/SHARE server to execute.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ALLOCATE SASFILE SAS-data-set1 <(data-set-options) > 
    <SAS-data-set2 <(data-set-options)> ... 
    SAS-data-set8 <(data-set-options)>>;

Specifies SAS data sets to open and keep in memory for the duration of a
SAS/SHARE server session.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Provides summary information about each server library that is currently defined to the server.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that this library will be used to cache catalogs that have been accessed  by means of the cross-architecture catalog access feature.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a standard SAS data file library. This is the default.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Is a numeric value that specifies the maximum number of catalog files that are held in the cache.
